"Alloparenting" is the scientific term for what you're doing:

[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alloparenting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alloparenting)

Wikipedia says that it "is known from 120 mammal and 150 bird species."  Ants/wasps/bees take it to the extreme.  Some primates do some alloparenting, but the only ones which do it as much as humans do are marmosets and tamarins:

[https://www.naturalhistorymag.com/features/09270/meet-the-alloparents?page=2](https://www.naturalhistorymag.com/features/09270/meet-the-alloparents?page=2)

Grandparenting is a subset of this behaviour pattern.

The scientist who has studied this more than probably anybody else is Sarah Blaffer Hrdy, and I learned most of it from her book "Mothers and Others":

[https://www.hup.harvard.edu/books/9780674060326](https://www.hup.harvard.edu/books/9780674060326)

The Gay Uncle Hypothesis.  

It ties into some evidence that homosexuality may be the result of epigenetic events during fetal development as a result of mom's DNA.

Basically, if an early human woman had a gay brother and her male mate got eaten by a sabertooth tiger or squished by a mammoth, there was an extra male who likely didn't have children and had close ties and would increase the chances of her children surviving. 

If Krogette inherited the gene from her mother, this makes her male children more likely to be gay which acts as the same benefit for her potential daughters and their children.

That also lines up with the fact that the chances of being gay increases with the more older brothers a man has. Ensure the continuation of your line with elder sons, and then have younger childless gay sons to help protect their nieces and nephews

I like to call them spare tire offspring; you don't need five wheels to drive a sedan, but it's still useful to have a spare tire.

The birth order effect prevents an excess of siblings competing for the same limited amount of resources/mates while still being useful in other ways (providing alloparenting, being a backup option since they can technically mate if needed, etc.)

Evolutionary biologists are well aware that there's a tendency among non-specialists to believe that any and every observable feature is a result of evolutionary pressure. In reality, many traits exist simply due to random mutations or practices that are evolutionarily neutral, or which are artifacts of a different factor.

So it's entirely possible (I would say, even likely) that we have menopause simply as an evolutionarily-advantageous energy-saving factor in early life. The developing female fetus spends the energy required producing enough eggs to last her through a normal lifespan, and no more. The fact that (under the normal conditions that shaped our evolution) a few individuals lived longer than that is largely irrelevant as far as evolutionary selection goes. If you haven't successfully reproduced and raised kids by the time you're 50-ish, the chance that you'll do so successfully thereafter is pretty slim, even if you remain fertile, so it's hard to see a a selective advantage there.

We see this in immunology, too. People ask why our immune system starts to fail decades before we actually die. And it's true, our immune systems peak in late childhood through adolescence as organs such as the thymus start to involute and atrophy. Over time, this leads to a gradual immune imbalance that we refer to as immunosenescence, which starts to become clinically relevant around the age of 50. From there on, we rapidly become more susceptible to infection and cancer and less able to repair trauma. From the point of view of the older individual, this is most definitely not a useful evolutionary advantage. But producing all these immune cells (most of which rapidly die) is a very energy intensive process. There's an obvious advantage to shutting it down when you no longer need it. Earlier in our evolutionary history, when most people were dead by 50, and when their chance of reproductive success was extremely low by that point, there was no counterbalancing advantage.

So, like menopause, it's quite possible that the outcomes we see in older life are simply a result of the fact that for most of our evolutionary history that "older life" barely existed.

Women don‚Äôt produce enough eggs to last a typical lifespan and never have. The estimated human lifespan, after accounting for childhood mortality rates, has always reached into the sixties when women would be incapable of reproducing (https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2868286/).

Yes there was a study that showed more autistic children were born to women that took acetaminophen in the study than those that did not, but that's all the study stated. It did not conclude that there was a definite link between the two because _correlation does not equal causation._ It's like saying eating ice cream must cause shark attacks since more shark attacks happen when people eat more ice cream in the summer. They can be happening at the same time without one of them directly causing the other.

The hidden link there is that autistic people feel pain more strongly than people without autism, and the only safe painkiller for pregnant women is acetaminophen. Autistic parents are more likely to have autistic children, and pregnant autistic women take more Tylenol.

From what I have read I agree that that is very likely why but without more studies we can't say for sure.


It could also be that women tend to take acetaminophen when they have a fever and the elevated body temperature affects the developing baby's brain. Or it could be that women who tend to take acetaminophen while pregnant already have other underlying health issues like joint issues or obesity or anxiety that would affect the baby's health. This is misleading. The article is only claiming that mitochondrial DNA remains mutation free not the nuclear DNA. The correlation between age and egg quality decline is well established.
The risk of trisomy 21 increases with age, for example.

As others have noted though, it's different between the sexes though in that while women have a hard stop, men don't hit that wall but instead have degrading sperm health. They can father children even as very old men - like Jacques Cousteau having his last child at 72 - though with much higher risks to the offspring than a younger father.

Also worth pointing out is that the hard stop women experience is the end of fertility as in no more eggs, but it isn't necessarily the end of their reproductive life. Hormone replacements and IVF can allow a post-menopausal woman to still carry a pregnancy.

Really the two issues go together.

1) childbirth is extremely risky and over 40, before modern medicine, would have a very high mortality rate. The result is that nature wouldn‚Äôt select for mothers who could have children later in life because so few would produce enough additional offspring to affect the population.

And

2) Having older women as part of the group was generally beneficial and helped families thrive. So natural selection favored families where women more often survived past 40. This would have favored families with the genetic traits of menopause because of the very high mortality rate for women giving birth after 40 without modern medicine.

This is also why the trait is somewhat unique. You need both the high risk of death of the mother in childbirth and a social structure that allows younger generations to do better because of the existence of older generations of non-childbearing adults for this dynamic to exist.

You neatly summarise two important mechanisms that can explain menopause. To add to this, human children demand an enormous amount of care for a long time. Losing their parents or caretakers may severely screw up a child, severely reducing their chances at becoming functional adults. Menopause starts around 50, which effectively means the woman may well be past 65 (which probably was very old in prehistoric times) before her offspring is capable of taking care of themselves. In an evolutionary perspective, when the likelihood of birth complications increases dramatically and you may well die before they reach adulthood, at this point ensuring that your current children and grandchildren reaches adulthood as healthy, functional adults becomes more beneficial to spreading your genes than giving birth to more children.
The older you are the higher the chances of complications, but you can still help rear children including your grandchildren even if you aren't fertile

"Alloparenting" is the scientific term for what you're doing:

[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alloparenting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alloparenting)

Wikipedia says that it "is known from 120 mammal and 150 bird species."  Ants/wasps/bees take it to the extreme.  Some primates do some alloparenting, but the only ones which do it as much as humans do are marmosets and tamarins:

[https://www.naturalhistorymag.com/features/09270/meet-the-alloparents?page=2](https://www.naturalhistorymag.com/features/09270/meet-the-alloparents?page=2)

Grandparenting is a subset of this behaviour pattern.

Evolutionary biologists are well aware that there's a tendency among non-specialists to believe that any and every observable feature is a result of evolutionary pressure. In reality, many traits exist simply due to random mutations or practices that are evolutionarily neutral, or which are artifacts of a different factor.

So it's entirely possible (I would say, even likely) that we have menopause simply as an evolutionarily-advantageous energy-saving factor in early life. The developing female fetus spends the energy required producing enough eggs to last her through a normal lifespan, and no more. The fact that (under the normal conditions that shaped our evolution) a few individuals lived longer than that is largely irrelevant as far as evolutionary selection goes. If you haven't successfully reproduced and raised kids by the time you're 50-ish, the chance that you'll do so successfully thereafter is pretty slim, even if you remain fertile, so it's hard to see a a selective advantage there.

We see this in immunology, too. People ask why our immune system starts to fail decades before we actually die. And it's true, our immune systems peak in late childhood through adolescence as organs such as the thymus start to involute and atrophy. Over time, this leads to a gradual immune imbalance that we refer to as immunosenescence, which starts to become clinically relevant around the age of 50. From there on, we rapidly become more susceptible to infection and cancer and less able to repair trauma. From the point of view of the older individual, this is most definitely not a useful evolutionary advantage. But producing all these immune cells (most of which rapidly die) is a very energy intensive process. There's an obvious advantage to shutting it down when you no longer need it. Earlier in our evolutionary history, when most people were dead by 50, and when their chance of reproductive success was extremely low by that point, there was no counterbalancing advantage.

So, like menopause, it's quite possible that the outcomes we see in older life are simply a result of the fact that for most of our evolutionary history that "older life" barely existed.

Women don‚Äôt produce enough eggs to last a typical lifespan and never have. The estimated human lifespan, after accounting for childhood mortality rates, has always reached into the sixties when women would be incapable of reproducing (https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2868286/).

Really the two issues go together.

1) childbirth is extremely risky and over 40, before modern medicine, would have a very high mortality rate. The result is that nature wouldn‚Äôt select for mothers who could have children later in life because so few would produce enough additional offspring to affect the population.

And

2) Having older women as part of the group was generally beneficial and helped families thrive. So natural selection favored families where women more often survived past 40. This would have favored families with the genetic traits of menopause because of the very high mortality rate for women giving birth after 40 without modern medicine.

This is also why the trait is somewhat unique. You need both the high risk of death of the mother in childbirth and a social structure that allows younger generations to do better because of the existence of older generations of non-childbearing adults for this dynamic to exist.

You neatly summarise two important mechanisms that can explain menopause. To add to this, human children demand an enormous amount of care for a long time. Losing their parents or caretakers may severely screw up a child, severely reducing their chances at becoming functional adults. Menopause starts around 50, which effectively means the woman may well be past 65 (which probably was very old in prehistoric times) before her offspring is capable of taking care of themselves. In an evolutionary perspective, when the likelihood of birth complications increases dramatically and you may well die before they reach adulthood, at this point ensuring that your current children and grandchildren reaches adulthood as healthy, functional adults becomes more beneficial to spreading your genes than giving birth to more children.

>The **grandmother hypothesis** is a hypothesis to explain the existence of [menopause](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menopause) in human life history by identifying the adaptive value of extended kin networking.
